alert.note: Alert for Darlington; Florence (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 31 at 11:37AM EDT until September 03 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Dillon, Marion and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...North Carolina... Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Florence and Marion Counties. Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Great Pee Dee River...including Bennettsville 10sw, Pee Dee...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE SUNDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Black Creek at Quinby. * WHEN...Until late Sunday evening. * IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Floodwaters enter numerous homes on Creekside Drive, East Black Creek Road and Crooked Creek Drive. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 10.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 15.1 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage late Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by late tonight.
